Description:
The verb needs the prepositional object; nach introduces the object being the "aim of doing something".
(nach Glück streben, nach Aufmerksamkeit verlangen)
The verb needs a subject and a prepositional object which is introduced by the preposition vor.
The verb needs apart from subject two prepositional objects: the first one has to be introduced by mit, the second one by über.
The Experiencer gets the first position in the syntax. The verb is congruent with X.
The verb needs a dative object, which is generally human.
exceptional frame for sentences in which the original place holding subject (es) is omitted and the dative object gets the first position in the syntax

In this coding frame the Locative argument is introduced by a locative preposition which can govern different cases (dependent on the preposition choice). Alternatively it can be expressed by a locative adverb. The present representation generalizes across different prepositions (and different cases of the nouns governed by the prepositions).

Comment: The Russian "prepositional" case is abbreviated loc (locative), following Timberlake (2004).
The Russian "prepositional" case is abbreviated loc (locative), following Timberlake (2004).

Description: 3 is the thing or skill taught. It can also be an infinitive like plavat' ‘to swim’

The coding frame is derived by means of the Reflexive Middle from an intransitive verb. The original actor optionally appears as a dative argument here, while the verb agrees with an (implicit, not overt) 3rd person singular neuter expletive subject (analogous to English it).
The agent argument of the basic coding frame can only appear in the Instrumental case if no instrument is present.
The agent argument of the basic coding frame can only appear in the Instrumental case if no instrument is present.

Comment: The accusative marker can be dropped.

Description: An intransitive predication where the verb assigns the accusative

avalent predication
No dummy arguments whatsoever
Experiencers are marked with the dative. The word class of the predicate can be ADJ, N, or V.

This is considered the most common coding frame in Yaqui due to the decision that was taken about the basic form of the equipolent verbs. All of these verbs are listed in their transitive form as the basic.

The coding frame shows an instrument participant, which is represented as optional (by means of the parentheses). Cases like this are considered 'extended coding frames', since they show other possible participants, although the basic frame is the one represented out of the parentheses.
The participant marked with the locative -po is necessary for the verb.
This is the construction of double object. Both of them are marked with the accusative suffix -ta.
use of jiʔį̄ is optional
The basic ditransitive frame. Note that here it is the recipient, not the patient, that is encoded by the undergoer slot, and that dual vs non-dual coding is sensitive to.
Transitive frame plus instrumental NP

Used with verbs of removal.
Could be regarded simply as a normal transitive frame, with ablative adjunct.
Source takes complex case (ablative built on dative) when human.
This is the basic frame for inherent middle verbs; used for many concepts normally expressed by intransitive verbs cross-linguistically.
Unusual pattern: case frame like transitive, verb morphology like middle. So far only attested with ors 'to leave'.
Verbs of verbal influence taking infinitive complement
2 is semantically restricted to cognate objects like zi 'word'
The coding frame E-dat > V.subj[M] > M refers to the pattern where the Experiencer is realized by a pronoun (e.g. gli piace la matematica).

Monovalent single-argument verb frame; a mew adpositional phrase to incorporate a further participant is only reluctantly (if animate) or somewhat readily (if inanimate and semantically primed, e.g. ruka mew 'in the house) accepted in elicitation, and infrequently found in texts
Bipersonal transitive frame plus oblique/adjunct
Comment: The adposition mew covers a wide range of semantic roles: source, goal, location, afficiary, cause, recipient, topic, instrument, etc.

Description: Extended monopersonal intransitive frame; the adpositional phrase is readily produced in elicitation and not infrequent in texts
Monopersonal dummy subject frame; no NP is accepted.
The verb is followed by a verbal directional, if the event is dynamic.

Comment: Clauses with two NPs (agent and patient) have to be in passive.

Description: This is a particular case of the standard intransitive frame Subject > Verb, with an 'associative extension' of the subject NP; the preposition ning is used in a construction superficially similar to NP coordination, but is clearly comitative in its semantics
Dative-marked recipient/beneficiary frame with a subset of (potentially semantically) ditransitive predicates.
Standard transitive frame: ergative marking is usual, but not obligatory.
Transitive coding frame with bivalent atelic activity predicates; only in combination with inflecting verbs gagba 'be' or gajgany 'go' in their atelic reading.
Verbless clause with nominal predicate.

Typically, locative marking is omitted with place names, but also with inherently locative nominals like yagbali 'place, home, camp'. Locative marking is occasionally replaced with purposive marking when L denotes the habitat of animal species with the verb gagba 'be'.
Ditransitive (double absolutive) frame; recipient indexed on verb.
Default intransitive construction with absolutive S and S agreement on morphologically intransitive verb.
Coding frame for predicates of transfer. The goal argument can be marked with either locative or allative case (not considered here separately as a case of alternation).

Basic transitive construction:
[ [ Pn ]PC.i [ W ]V.tr -Absj [ P ]NP.j [ A ]NP .i ]VCC
"A affects / acts on P."
The transitive subject function (actor) is the same for different semantic roles, including agents and experiencers. The subject and direct object (P) are cross-referenced on the transitive verb. The actants themselves are optional, not case-marked and may occur in any order, although subject-final order is the default.

Construction of ditransitive verb with animate indirect complement:
[ [ Pn ]PC.i [ W ]V.tr -Absj [ P ]NP.j [ A ]NP.i [ ti’ [ L ]NP ]PrepP ]VCC
"A acts upon P with respect to L."
This is a subtype of the construction of ditransitive verb with inanimate indirect complement.

V is a three-argument verb which is typically derived by causative, applicative or applicative-causative derivations. Core arguments are unmarked for case. In verbal cross-referencing (indices) of transitive verbs, A affixes are normally placed before P markers but when it comes to the interaction of first and second person participants there is also a number of fusional markers (A+P), which are subject to considerable dialectal variation. The third person (A/P) is always zero-marked.

Word order. According to Tamura (2000: 181), the basic word order is A > R > T. However, one finds numerous word order variations in actual text, which are probably not syntactically but pragmatically motivated; this issue requires extensive corpus based research in the future.

REF: Tamura, Suzuko. (1988) 2000. “Ainugo” [The Ainu language]. In Kamei, Takashi, Rokuroo Koono, and Eiichi Chino (eds.). Gengogaku daijiten. vol. 1, Tokyo: Sanseidoo, 6-94. English version: The Ainu language. (ICHEL Linguistic Studies vol. 2), Tokyo: Sanseidoo.
It is a monotransitive pattern, the locative participant is encoded as an oblique with locative/allative postposition.

This in an indirective ditransitive construction. Rs are marked by the dative case postposition eun ‘to/toward (sb)’, which is employed for marking animate obliques such as Recipient, Addressee or animate Goal (ex. 41), and is distinguished from un ‘to/towards (sth)’, which is employed for marking inanimate Goal obliques (ex. 43).
It should be noted that the frequency of the eun-marked indirective ditransitive construction in texts is rather low and that it is preferably used with those few verbs for which there are no corresponding Recipient/Addressee applicatives. In other words, if there is a Recipient/Addressee applicative in ko- (ex. 42), the eun-marked indirective construction, has a low chance of occurring in texts, and completely no chance of occurring if R is encoded by a pronominal argument (ex. 42).
The above-mentioned frequency restriction does not apply to the cases where R participant is, strictly speaking, not a Recipient proper, i.e. un-marked indirective construction with inanimate Goal and wa-marked indirective construction with animate/inanimate Source: they are fairly frequent in texts regardless of the existence/non-existence of the corresponding applicative constructions.

Core arguments are unmarked for case.
In verbal cross-referencing (indices) of transitive verbs, A affixes are normally placed before P markers but when it comes to the interaction of first and second person participants there is also a number of fusional markers (A+P), which are subject to considerable dialectal variation. The third person (A/P) is always zero-marked.
This coding frame is mainly for ditratransitive verbs in which fún introduces the third argument, i.e., the recipient.
In this coding frame, fi is used to introduce the instrument argument in the basic construction.
